case_vignette:
A 33-year-old Black man presents to a dermatology clinic with a 5-month history of asymptomatic lesions on his arms and trunk. He is otherwise healthy with no personal or family history of skin disease. He has no history of fever, cough, shortness of breath, or joint pain. The patient has not tried any treatments for these lesions. On examination, there are several smooth, well-demarcated hypopigmented plaques on his upper arms and left flank. He has no similar lesions elsewhere on his body. The patient is concerned about the appearance of these lesions and wants to know if they are cancerous.

I have some smooth, light-colored patches on my upper arms and left side that don't hurt or itch.

No, I am otherwise healthy and not experiencing any other symptoms or taking any medications.
Final Diagnosis: Vitiligo
